review_title: Many excellent benefits, review based on a previous administration
job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Flagstaff, AZ
pros:
The best benefit of working for NAU is the benefits. I've worked for NAU (state government), for the federal government and in the non-profit sector. Of the benefits I received, NAU's were the best in terms of paid leave (both sick and vacation) as well as their retirement matching (both for service professional and classified staff employment categories). The medical insurance was excellent, offering low-cost options on campus which could be optionally paired with large provider networks through BCBS. Of the sectors I have worked in NAU was also hands-down the best about tuition support as they have a tuition waiver with ABOR if you are a full time salaried employee. 

I worked as a systems analyst primarily with web application development and another significant boon was that the team I worked with used modern technologies, was open to innovation and provided considerable opportunities to build skill in enterprise application development with emerging technologies.
cons:
Though the benefits were so good, I ultimately opted to leave NAU because I did not feel my job was secure. I worked during the "Cheng administration", whose MO was to systematically cut resources to university staff and departments while centralizing control across university departments under the university president. For that reason during my time working as a student and staff member for 6 years at NAU there was consistent, widespread upheaval and dissatisfaction across the university both from students and staff. When I became salaried staff as a service professional, the president had to "personally sign" a contract renewing my service every 6 months though I was considered a fully salaried employee of the university. Furthermore, although working for this sector would seem to imply a better work-life balance than private industry, the resource cutting led to staff routinely working unpaid overtime hours to make up for under-staffing. I knew some people in my office were sometimes working as much as 80 hours per week. I came to feel that 6 month contract renewing and chronic understaffing did not bode well and I left NAU. I believe that this was an administration-specific problem but I did not want to hold out for an administration change. 

Some other cons are that in general salary does not match cost of living in Flagstaff (somewhat low). This has impacts to the community as NAU is the largest employer, thereby setting a generally low bar for income in Flagstaff. Furthermore, there is little movement in promotion potential. Whereas you might be able to "move up" within 2-3 years in some organizations I felt I was likely to have to wait 5-7 years or diversify and leave my team for promotion.

review_title: Great work environment, fabulous benefits, low pay
pros: Great state retirement plan (vested 100% after five years). Cheap and good health benefits include Blue Cross and Blue Shield, for very low monthly premium. Low stress environment and opportunities for training abound. There are many intellectual opportunities. The tuition discounts are terrific. The campus is gorgeous, with many trees and even a pdeestrian walkway that bisects the campus. Flagstaff is an interesting city with a great city library, places to hike and bike, no lack of shopping, organic food markets and farmer's markets, and lots of community events of cultural interest. My co-workers are interesting and congenial. Work environment is very pleasant.
cons: Flagstaff is a terribly expensive city for housing, food, and utilities. No one seems to shovel the walkways when there is snow and ice. Inadequate and expensive parking -- sometimes you can't even park where you work. Some buildings are past their usefulness, due to safety issues. Some asst. professors have terrible office space, such as an office built at the bottom of an old swimming pool, with no windows. The NAU library is not as well-stocked as other universities. The doctoral programs are very few. NAU makes it difficult to enroll in online classes for other universities. It has to be done manually, not online. There seems to be a lot of crime in this city, and on campus. I usually like to belong to some sort of professional writers' group, but none exist here.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: My coworkers were great, and the relationships you make with the students really powers you through the rest of the bureaucracy. The Maricopa campus I was on was incredibly nice to me.
cons:
You don't get paid a living wage, and there is nowhere to move up. 
If you work on the Maricopa campuses for which you're the only NAU employee on campus, you will be expected to do all of the following: 
1. Recruit at all events and classrooms on campus
2. Advise students and be available for walk ins (the campus I was on had about 9k students attending per semester)
3. Keep up your CRM including the 2 emails and 2 phone numbers you have
4. Be your own office manager including ordering office supplies and new NAU material when you're out (we don't get student workers or a receptionist)
5. Be a career/life coach for all your students
6. Maintain a relationship with the Maricopa campus
7. Complete call campaigns 300 people long in a timely fashion

All for under $40k (before taxes!) and be blamed when the numbers are down because you weren't doing one of the above enough. Also, there is little to no marketing for the Phoenix programs.

job_title: Systems Support Analyst in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: The people that work at NAU have the same Flagstaff attitude - positive and very community based.  There is a general 'can-do' attitude by the employees who are always asked to do more with less.
cons: The salary structure at NAU is ridiculous, management restructures departments several months before reviews and does not take into account past reviews before the restructures.  I have been here for almost three years (with fifteen years of prior experience) and I am making close to entry level for my pay grade, with no raises yet.  Our department is woefully understaffed and has done more with less for so long that management has no incentive to give us more resources.

review_title: Nice people, bad management, worse leadership
job_title: Systems Software Engineer, Senior in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: casual environment, lots of time of for service professionals, tuition reduction, flex schedule
cons: the university has a category of employees which it calls "Service Professionals", it might as well be called "contract for hire, until we don't like/want/need you anymore". These employees get "higher" pay, but have to deal with 6 month contracts, with an option to extend to a year. Every year as a service professional you pray you didn't upset someone off too much that your contract does not get renewed. The university has the right to cancel your contract at any time, giving you 90 days severance (which is not bad) but really its moving money, because chances of landing a similar type of job in flagstaff for the equal pay are slim to none.  If the university cancels your contract, they do not have to give you a reason, which is convenient for them because a lot of dubious unethical (though not illegal) activities can happen depending on where you work or who your supervisor is.

review_title: Supportive and caring academic context in a university that needs to grow
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: There are wonderful professionals who truly care about teaching. NAU is generally laid back, as academic environments. There is a strong sense of community among grad students generally and among anyone you choose to connect. Administrators and faculty work hard to create opportunities for students. The Graduate College in particular is very supportive with fellowships, travel funding, and frequent events for professional and personal development.
cons: NAU experiences some growing pains and organizational change. Some procedures seem not to make sense from the grad student perspective, and there can be high turnover in some areas. Some of the student population takes a negative view of administration, at times. Grad students can do really well by having a positive attitude, developing personal relationships (including beyond their own department or area), and recognizing how the university responds to pressure to grow.

pros: Job security, good benefits, good public transportation, living in Flagstaff
cons: Very low wages, raises are rare, no incentive to work harder.  Basically, all of the bad stereotypes one may hear of about working for the government are exemplified here - many employees do not care, abuse of overtime hours (making most employees - even many entry level employees - exempt), incredibly disorganized and inefficient management structure, promotions NOT based on performance, ability or skill - unless you are a service professional or have a PhD, you need to be a female or minority to move up.

pros: Co-workers are great. Benefits are great. The work isn't that hard but it is up to you on how you keep your area clean.
cons: The pay here isn't great. Pay raises are small and yearly which is like 3 to 5 cents which isn't something to be proud of. You ask about raises and they say they don't have enough but then you see new buildings being put up and the president gets a bonus of 40,000 on top of her 520,000 dollar paycheck. Our machines here are just old and falling apart. We have some custodians here that are homeless and just a couple years back we had one pass away in the snow because he didn't have a place to stay so he was out in the cold, he was even a veteran. This wasn't even put in the paper for people to know whats going on here.

review_title: Morale at institution is low, and human resource policies are oppressive.  They get away with murder because they are ed
pros: Flagstaff is beautiful, and it is wonderful tob live at 7,000 feet elevation.  The campus is beautiful, but small and surrounded by two different cemetaries.
cons: Northern Arizona University is one of only three big employers in the small town of approximately 50,000 to 60,000 people (counting students).  It is a Small Town, and after a year you have done everything and met everyone.  Management hires for only one year at a time.  So if they don't like you, and you don't put in 60 hours a week but get paid for 40 hours a week, they will not rehire you each year.  It is hard to purchase a house with this job instability.

review_title: Experience working for the Office of Sustainability
pros:
- Limitless opportunities for implementing projects across campus.
- Family-like environment.
- Openness of the management for new visions, new ways and new goals.
- Great supervision with a big push towards individual growth.
- Easy interdepartmental communication.
- Grassroots support for any sustainability-related initiative management is trying to push through.
- Great location with endless outdoors activities and gorgeous landscapes anywhere you go!
- Opportunity to take free classes as a full-time employee, contributing to a constant personal and professional growth.
cons:
- Institutional resistance to change.
- Lack of direction for some of the sustainability-related organizations.
- Lack of student engagement in sustainability-related initiatives.
- Lack of team work experience.

All the above mentioned cons can always become an opportunity for change. NAU management is highly flexible and open to any changes like that.

review_title: President Haeger is building his legacy while the academic institution crumbles around all the new buildings.
pros: Great Benefits! Reduced tuition for all nuclear family members. There are a number of invested people in the school, and they go out of their way to improve the place as far as they have authority.
cons:
There is no such thing as institutional vitality. It is a red-tape cloaked bureaucracy, and filled with "lifers," those that fell into a position, and will be there, doing the same repetitive actions until they are carried out on a stretcher.
It has been known to happen that an employee will be ashamed of the high work ethic of a new hire (he's making us all look bad) and clamored to have him fired.

review_title: Fun, works well with classes, but lots of red tape.

cons: Stipend pay is very low, difficult for the current state of the economy.  Over abundance of trainings and meetings that are often redundant, time consuming, and mostly common sense.  Lots of red tape for everything, want a new stapler for the desk? fill out a form wait 2-3 weeks.  Some policies will cause you to sacrifice your individuality, mainly in the political field acceptable forms of expression depend on the political views of your supervisor.

cons: Parking is a nightmare.  I had to run into my office one night (~10 pm) to pick up papers to grade, and my option was to either park in the building parking lot for the building, or park 10 mins away. since i was going to be in and out in less than 10 minutes, and since it was 10 at night, at parked at the building.   10 minutes later i have a $90 parking ticket.

pros: I have taught here since 1989.   Some call it  “ poverty with a view “  and indeed the salaries are lower here than at the other two state universities. But my experience has been largely positive. I love the student population, some of them first generation students excited to be learning and achieving their dreams.  There is a positive attitude here  of commitment and excellence.  It is a jewel and not really known throughout the country and really deserves more recognition for it’s outstanding faculty, research opportunities, artistic expression and individual accomplishment.
cons: For those who dislike cold weather and snow this is probably not the place for the faint of heart.

review_title: NAU is non-strategic and declining, but Flagstaff is nice!
pros:
Students: lots of first-generation, mostly hard-working and high-quality students who deserve and largely get a boost to compete in complex job markets.
Flagstaff: nice small city, with true winters and mild summers, trails and woods in easy reach, and major wilderness canyons and peaks not far.
cons:
Leadership: rarely visionary or empathetic, decisions are autocratically shoved down people's throats without even candy coating, with short-term constraints seeming to bounce the long-term future for a formerly proud organization -- not a promising trend in an increasingly competitive higher-education industry.
Flagstaff: high cost of living, infrastructure not keeping-up with growth, privately run student housing areas are noisy and trashed with little help from NAU.

pros: NAU has a wonderful environment to work in. The benefits are the best I've ever had!  The people there are wonderful. I loved working there! I was very sad to leave NAU.
cons: Sometimes supervisors can be very mean and have unreasonable expectations and if they are a tenured professor there is nothing that can be done about it The first 11 years I worked there I was promoted 4 times and it was wonderful but when I moved to another area for 8 years the office environment was miserable.

review_title: Opportunities galore to innovate, grow, and collaborate with a hard-working team
pros: University College is an incredible community to work with. There's excitement about developing new programming, and assessing it using data driven measures, to contribute to student success. I've had lots of freedom and support to propose and prototype new ideas for programming, with a great team that shares my high expectations for quality work. My program director is very proactive about professional development, so our small team regularly attends conferences and pursues growth opportunities related to our areas of focus.
cons: The cost of living in Flagstaff is very high, and our salaries are on the low end of national averages.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: NAU is a very collegial place to work.  You feel like you are a valued member of a large group, and opinions and ideas can be exchanged freely (at least within my department).  Flagstaff is a great place to live and offers an unparalleled quality of life, especially if you enjoy outdoor activities.  I definitely feel that the work that I do for NAU is valued by students, other faculty members, and even administration.  I am very happy to work here.
cons: It would be nice to see the university allocate more funds towards teaching and research rather than on new buildings.

review_title: Beautiful backdrop but an abysmal payscale.

cons: Payscale is abysmal. Hiring too many lecturers, instructors, and part time persons--many of whom are well (over) qualified for their jobs. NOT rewarding the faculty they do have when tenure track lines are available but are instead replacing them with the next shiny best thing.

cons: NAU provides low pay for graduate students especially for those that teach large enrollment lecture sections that would normally be taught by a full professor.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros:
NAU is still fairly small, and it's easy to get into (I was a GTA).
The class I taught (ENG 105) can be plug-and-play or you can make it totally your own, so if you're into teaching, it's great professional development.
cons: If you're not planning on teaching your entire career, NAU lacks other types of professional development (at least the English Writing department does -- other departments might have plenty of research or other jobs).

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: I was a teaching assistant for the mechanical engineering department. The pros were: flexible hours, good pay, fun and easy work, and the ability to work while still being in school.
cons: I enjoyed this job very much and found very little not to like about it. The one downside would be the large amount of time spent grading class assignments.

pros:
- Great scheduling, if you're a student. 
- Entitled to a lot of breaks during shifts.
- Room for immediate but slight growth.
cons:
- No immediate benefits outside of scheduling. 
- No overtime.
- Raises come in very long intervals, years at a time. Even then, they're laughable. 
- Can only work up to 30 hours if you're a full-time student or taking any classes as a student.
- Taxed higher in summer time because why not.
- Being a student worker.
- Rampant violations to the agreement made between the student workers and management, by management.

pros: The benefits are great, the salary is so-so (depending on what department you're in).  Once you get your foot in the door, there are a lot of opportunities.
cons: Government job with a lot of people who have the "government job" mindset.  Management doesn't seem to know what's going on half the time with their own department.

review_title: Arizona GEAR UP State Office @ NAU-North Valley: Run! Don't Walk!
job_title: Administrative Assistant @ State Office in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
The federal GEAR UP grant helps a lot of students in their quest to create a better life for themselves. Arizona GEAR UP does a better job than other GEAR UP grant offices in other states. Arizona does a lot of good for their students.

Working at the State Office of Arizona GEAR UP looks great on your resume, especially since it's in conjugation with Northern Arizona University. The benefits are great.
cons:
I was an admin assistant with executive assistant functions because 2 executive assistants quit in a short amount of time, one prior to my being there and one just after I started. I walked into a toxic work environment. The managers do not like the director, who is polite and stand offish, but freaks out on us if something doesn't go smoothly. She is a narcissist and blames others for her honest mistakes, however harmless they are. The managers are also in 3 distinct cliques. This is hard to navigate because there are so few employees in the State Office of Arizona GEAR UP. One of the mangers is the director's best friend and that's like having 2 bosses. 

My first year was a training year but no one let me do my job because they're control freaks. I brought it up to my supervisor at my annual evaluation and he said he knew and to just roll with it. Thankfully, I left after 2.5 years because I was being bullied by half the managers and it was becoming ugly. They started tricking me and stealing my belongings out of my receptionist's desk in an effort to get me to quit. I never responded hate with hate. I think most of this was in part because I found out they were mis-spending federal grant money. They were trying to bait me into saying or doing something against policy or get me fired so I'd look like a disgruntled employee. They replaced me NOT with another admin asst but a data entry specialist. Their financial manager left soon after I did and I think it was because of this misuse of funds. 

The State of AZ forces you into their retirement & medical insurance programs, so, potentially, a large part of your paycheck goes towards this.

The North Valley Campus is depressing. 

The staff on this campus engage in gossip like they've got nothing better to do.

job_title: Support Systems Analyst in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Work environment is generally less stressful and with a more relaxed atmosphere than many corporate jobs. Opportunities for continued education are numerous including reduced tuition for self and family members. Benefits package is one of the best in the state.
cons: Pay rates are consistently below industry averages. Some departments are better than others with salary. Some departments are more corporate in environment while many are more relaxed.

job_title: Applications Analyst Senior in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: The benefits are okay, but I wouldn't count on them in the future.
cons: Since Rita Chang became president, it's become a toxic work culture.  A bureaucratic fiefdom, there is more infighting than cooperation.  My supervisor went from being a relatively affable person to a real jerk.

job_title: Undergraduate Researcher, Office Assistant, TA, Grader, SI in Flagstaff, AZ
pros:
Lots of opportunities for students to work:
- Get to know your Department Chair and see if they need help in the office
- Research opportunities (especially in CEFNS)
- Flexible hours (usually)
- You can usually schedule work when you are already planning on being on campus
- Long- and short-term employment opportunities
cons: Depending on the position you apply for, your hours may not be as flexible. While I had great experiences working at NAU while I attended, I know many people who did not enjoy their campus jobs.

review_title: Great research, small university but great benefits.
pros: Great town, beautiful location, lots of interesting research going on around campus.  Opportunities are also available for collaborations with the other AZ state schools.
cons: Funding for research is much lower compared to the other state schools.  Cost of living is fairly high.  Would like more resources for staff and post-docs on campus, for networking, as well as extracurricular activities.  Additionally, the gym memberships are rather expensive, and piecemeal-it's extra for pool, classes, etc., which is different from other universities at which I've worked.

pros: Great atmosphere with mostly great people. Flagstaff is an outdoor enthusiast's dream. Classes challenge students to not only memorize information, but synthesize and apply it. World renowned lab and research facilities.
cons: Trying to improve courses and the workload on teaching assistants has been near impossible. Supervisors are not open to suggestions and want to do things their micromanaging and unnecessary ways. Upper management listens to suggestions, but can't really do much to fix any concerns that teaching assistants have. Supervisors expect far too much time and effort from teaching assistants.

review_title: Great benefits, ability to move within organization
pros: Job security is high; except in cases of statewide layoffs, you won't lose your job. I had a fairly wide amount of latitude to decide what I wanted to work on at any given time.
cons: Hard to get in, because in a lot of cases, a job posting is basically a mirage; they've already decide who they're going to hire, so you have no chance. The law requires them to post all jobs, so there's no way to tell when this is the case.

review_title: NAU provides a superb and friendly work environment with supportive faculty and students who are a pleasure to teach.
pros: Faculty at NAU will go out of their way to help others and are among the devoted to teaching undergraduates. The students are bright and a blast to teach and very down-to-earth.
cons: Salaries are significantly lower than other institutions, and the University is cutting back on tenure-track positions due to budgetary reasons.

pros: The other people working at NAU are all very nice. There is definitely a sense of "family" among the other faculty. My supervisor was flexible, and I had a lot of input in when I could teach, etc.
cons: My position required many more hours than I was paid to do- I was contracted to work 20 hours as a part-time instructor, but would spend many more hours for class-prep, grading, etc. I guess that's the nature of the beast when working in academia, I suppose.

review_title: Pretty sure they are trying to get us to leave...
pros:
Flexible Hours, usually.  
Most people genuinely care for the students.
cons:
The morale around campus is terrible.  We hear management talking about "salary savings"... and many of our most talented coworkers are leaving.  I am pretty sure they are trying to make it so terrible to work here that they want us to leave... so they don't have to refill the position.
Parking permits are almost $500 a year now.

review_title: If things can be bad, the administration at NAU makes them worse.
pros: The students are fun to work with.
cons: The upper administration is short-sighted and ruthless. They treat the faculty and staff like crap, so it's a very painful place to work. There are so many creative and talented people, but they are beaten down so badly by ABOR, President Chang and her policies. Morale is in the gutter.

review_title: A  comfortable place to work; could use better leadership at all levels.
pros: Laid back, friendly, flexible atmosphere. Excellent benefits. Beautiful campus with lots of activity. Many interesting people and projects. Not particularly stressful.
cons: Low pay in a region that has a very high cost of living. Limited opportunities for raises, promotions. Too many people in positions of leadership lack decent leadership skills. Often takes a very long time to implement positive changes.

review_title: Welcoming and Pleasant Experience, Both for School and Work
pros: People are very friendly and helpful, working with professors is easy and insightful, recommended to attend for college or apply for job. Also the price for school is great (locked in for fours years)!
cons: NAU has yet to fully establish themselves as a great school for some of their programs, but the hands on experience that accompanies the classes is priceless!

pros: There is a great benefit plan, including health, life, vision, dental, and tuition assistance.The Flagstaff climate is great. Flagstaff is also a smaller fun city.
cons: NAU has terrible pay for employees, well-below average, and does not match cost-of-living in Flagstaff. Upper management does not respect lower employees, many are political appointees, and are not qualified for their positions. Campus is overcrowded.

review_title: Low faculty/staff morale due to top-down money-driven decisions
pros: Intelligent and compassionate colleagues you can commiserate with (depending on the department, of course). The location - beautiful hiking, biking, and camping spots. You'll notice that none of these pros is inherently NAU.
cons: If you're non-tenure track, your pay and future are pretty bleak. Poor administration and leadership. Issues brought to HR and Equity and Access do not seem to be addressed satisfactorily; they're just for documentation.

review_title: Mediocre experience overall, but best of the local options for full-time employment
pros: great benefits (health insurance, professional development, retirement options for Service Professionals), most entry- and mid-level peers and colleagues are excellent people and are in higher ed for the right reasons
cons: Low-end salaries and no performance or cost-of-living increases, very hard to advance or promote within a department, lots of behind-the-scenes appointments and assignments without communication or rationale, director level and higher interactions are very inconsistent and poorly disseminate communication about initiatives

review_title: My experience was short term, but I did enjoy the work I completed thoughout the semester.
job_title: Lab Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Individual college departments treat employees very well and are always there to help there employees.
cons: My personal feeling is NAU as a whole has begun to loose their obligation to its' students.

review_title: An excellent education from capable, motivated, and dedicated faculty.
pros: NAU is full of top-notch faculty, staff, and administrators who are willing to work for a lower pay grade at a less prestigious college in order to enjoy the amazing natural beauty and outdoor activities of the Flagstaff area.
cons: Pay grade is a little lower compared to the national average for similarly qualified academics.  NAU has taken some big funding hits in recent years due to Arizona's financial troubles.

job_title: Service Center Agent in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Flexibility, bosses care, the work environment is that of a big team, even a family. This job gives you discipline and helps you acquire mental toughness and empathy with your callers from multiple departments of NAU. You also learn lots of Financial Aid, Admissions and how student accounts work.
cons: Lack of benefits and hour constraint for students. Sometimes the job can be repetitive, but it needs to be done.

review_title: Student Technology Center- Good job, Good employer.
job_title: Student Computing Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Competitive hourly pay, with flexible working hours. During school I could drop and pick up shift throughout my week to counteract homework loads. Bosses are super relaxed and care about their employees.
cons: The STC is almost always open so its possible hours may suck. Sometimes the workload is slow, which leads to boredom of employees(depends on how you like to spend your time).

review_title: Supervisors willing to work with my schedule
pros: I worked for the Facility Services, Grounds Department and was very please to find out, the supervisors were very willing to work with my school schedule, were great people to be around (BBQ's often!) and in general very nice and easy to talk to.
cons: The pay isn't the greatest, but hey, we're student workers! Sometimes early work hours (7 am start on a Saturday or Sunday)

pros: The people are great. The benefits are great. Having access to a universities resources is great.
cons: Bureaucracy. Everything is very slow moving. New hires take months. Getting new positions approved can take years, if at all. Pay is abysmal.

pros: I was accommodated as a spousal hire, the department was great to work in, and the students were highly motivated.
cons: Administrative decisions seemed detrimental to the academic environment and administrators not representing faculty, especially contingent faculty, often appeared desensitized to the struggles of lecturers, instructors, and adjuncts.

review_title: It was a good place to learn and grow
pros: Everyone I worked with was willing and able to help and explain anything you wanted to know.  They really wanted to help you succeed and expected you to help others whenever possible.  They were always willing to work with your class schedule.
cons: Hours were sometimes unreliable in TVS.  Hours depended on sporting events.

pros: You'll get to create your own schedule and work around your classes.  Extremely close to everything you need, especially if you live on campus.
cons: Very low pay, very little advancement, very little marketable skills, nobody cares that you're a student trying to make ends meet

review_title: Educational institution focused on maintaining appearances.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Flexible, friendly. They never told me I could not take time off. Gave me an office, computer and benefits as a graduate student.
cons: They left me with little guidance. Some supervisors demanded more than others. Inconsistent work environment. Lots of office politics.

review_title: Laid back but full of drama.
pros: Decent pay for Flagstaff, laid back and fun work environment, challenging assignments. Lot's of departments to bounce around from and plenty of opportunities if you have the education.
cons: No training provided what so ever. Very much a "figure it out yourself" type of environment. You'll most likely have multiple bosses breathing down your neck at once.

pros: Waived tuition, good collaboration and teaching experience. Great hands-on experience teaching to different levels of undergraduate courses. Thorough access to professors and lab managers to help make the lab go smoothly. Health insurance is also available.
cons: Certain expectations beyond job description and not much meaningful input as a graduate student. Pay is not great, but is offset by tuition waiver and moderate cost of living in Flagstaff.

pros: I was able to make my own schedule, there was a coffee shop in my building, and my co-workers were friendly.
cons: They had unrealistic expectations of how much time a person is capable of working and there was a general lack of funding to maintain equipment.

job_title: Student Services Manager in Flagstaff, AZ

Fast paced environment, there's always something to learn
Good support system for handling escalated issues

Stressful work, lots of high volume days
You're expected to accommodate any changes to your job position, despite being a student worker (aka not full time)
Your coworkers and supervisors make a big difference as to whether or not you can tolerate the job

review_title: Busy work for Financial Aid Student Workers

pros: Workloads are light, with very regular hours and lots of time off.
cons: Still has the hallmarks of "old school" state employment--sense of entitlement, people entrenched in jobs for decades with little or no productive change. Very little room for vertical growth in job development.

pros: Flexible hours, great for student workers. Co-workers are fun to work with and have great attitudes. Able to work outside in a beautiful city/university.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Flagstaff, AZ

job_title: End-User Computing Specialist in Flagstaff, AZ

review_title: NAU cares about their student workers, and helps them gain knowledge and experience to take into the real world.
